properties.Name: Faville Prairie
properties.Description: This is a nearly flat plain which is interpreted to be a site of Lake Scuppernong, a proglacial lake existed during the deglaciation period of Wisconsin. The lake was located between Green Bay Lobe of the icesheet and the Jefferson moraine. 12000 years ago, Green Bay Lobe retreated farther north and opened the drainage route to another basin, so the lake level started to decline, and the lake vanished completely around 9000 years ago.

properties.Name: Waterloo Drumlin
properties.ImageCap1: The cross cut of the Waterloo Drumlin
properties.Description: This is one of the best-studied drumlins in the Midwest. Like other drumlins, it is elongated with an oreintation parallel to the flow direction of the ice. It is interpreted that the bulk part of this drumlin was formed by erosional process while the top till section might be formed by depositional process since fabrics within the top section of this drumlin have greater alignment than fabrics in lower sections.

properties.Name: Horicon Marsh
properties.ImageCap1: The marsh seen from the overlook
properties.ImageCap2: Niagara Escarpment seen from far field
properties.Description: This marsh is a remnant of a glacial lake. When Laurentide Ice Sheet was retreating, it left a recessional moraine that dammed melt water and formed a proglacial lake in this region. When the Rock River started to erode the moraine, the water level of this lake dropped and eventually it became a marsh. To the east, you can observe the Niagara Escarpment, a dolomite ridge extended from Door Peninsula to southeastern Wisconsin. Since dolomite is resistant, when Green Bay Lobe encountered the ridge from the west, it was compressed and thrusted so that more sediments were transported on top of the glacier, which contributed to the formation of the Kettle Moriane to the east of the Escarpment.

properties.Name: Campbellsport Drumlin Field
properties.Description: These drumlins formed as a result of the interactions between Green Bay Lobe and Lake Michigan Lobe. Their shapes are relatively equidimensional with steep slopes at all sides. Drumlins in this region is relatively poorly understood because of the lack of public lands that allow scientists to drill holes.

properties.Name: IAT Visitor Center
properties.ImageCap1: The overlook at the IAT center
properties.Description: This is the visitor center of the Ice Age Trail. It is on the Green Bay Lobe side of the Kettle Moraine. Here at the outlook, you can see a large moulin kame named Dundee Mountain.

properties.Name: White Kame
properties.Description: Another large moulin kame. Not visited.

properties.Name: Spruce Lake Bog
properties.Description: This lake is a kettle lake. When glacier retreats, some dead ice chunks were left behind and partially buried by sediments. When the ice melts, it forms a kettle lake. In this lake, some plants filled the edges of the pond and produced a floating mat near the edges. They made the water acidic so that no other plants can grow.

properties.Name: Butler Lake Park
properties.ImageCap1: The top of a sharp-crested esker
properties.Description: The Parnell Esker at this stop is a sharp-crested esker formed during the late stage of the glaciation. A typical sharp-crested esker is 10s of meters tall and 10s of meters wide, while could be several kms long. It has poorly sorted sediments that were deposited by fast-moving water that went downslope in the basal channals within the glacier.

properties.Name: Garriety Hill
properties.Description: The Garriety Hill is a very large moulin kame at the northern region of Kettle Moraine State Park. Moulin kames are usually isolated and surrounded by flat lands or hummocky landforms. They are formed by sediments washed into supraglacial channels connecting the moulin. After the moulin hits the bedrock, sediments accumulate there to form conic-shaped kames.

properties.Name: Parnell Tower
properties.Description: This tower is a good vista to observe the Kettle Moriane. The Kettle Moriane is not a typical moraine (made of till) but a complex made of eskers, kames and kettle lakes. It was created when Lake Michigan Lobe and Green Bay Lobe merged together. The formation of Kettle Moraine is illustrated by figures in Mickelson et al, 2011.

properties.Name: Ball Park
properties.Description: The step-like topography in this region indicates different stages of Lake Michigan when its lake levels were higher than today. The lake level of Lake Michigan is controlled by the extent of the ice sheet (the openning of drainage routes) and the isostatic rebound of the crust.

properties.Name: Two Creeks
properties.ImageCap1: The lake shore at Two Creeks buried ancient forest
properties.Description: Ancient forest beds are burried here at Two Creeks. Those forests were established during a retreat of the Laurentide Ice Sheet. When the glacier readvanced, the lake level of Lake Michigan went up so the forest was submerged. When the ice sheet re-entered this region, it covered the forest beds with tills.

properties.Name: Port Washington
properties.Description: Ideally, Port Washington has one of the best exposures of Ozaukee Member of Kewaunee Formation in SE Wisconsin. The entire stratigraphic column is 28m tall and can be divided into three general sections. The top 17m is Ozaukee Member of the till, which is in reddish color because its source is in Lake Superior Basin where the iron oxide is rich in bedrocks. The intermediate section is basically lake sediments of conglomerates and fine sands. It indicates a temporary retreat of the glacier in this region. The lower part is another till but not well exposed.

properties.Name: Near MKE
properties.Description: This is the site to see the Oak Creek and Holy Hill Formations and it is the best exposure of multiple tills in Wisconsin. We only saw snow and huge waves of Lake Michigan driven by the wind.
